body: A few nits then LGTM

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/6255847/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/6255847)

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

@lukecwik if you mean "default" auth, I'm thinking of the credentials set by the gcloud command on a local machine. My scenario is this:

I'm running a lot GCP services via Airflow (DataProc, BigQuery, Storage and DataFlow). They are all running in a Kubernetes cluster using a service-key generated via the console (JSON file). The problem I have is that the containers don't have gcloud command installed, so I need to pass the service-key (JSON) file as a parameter to the jar (I'm always packing everything in a single JAR), but currently there is only support for the P12 (old keyfiles). Hence the PR.
R: @jbonofre
Testing ...

We already support using JSON files via default auth:
https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/application-default-credentials
Just requires you to set GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS env variable to point to the json file.

Integrating with gcloud-java-core would add the benefit of allowing us to get the project id from the credentials when using service accounts and not need to rely for users to specify it.
A few nits, but LGTM
R: @bjchambers
LGTM

Rebased and updated.

@lukecwik : thanks for clarifying. Learned something new today. I'm going to try playing with the env variable. But does this block this block this PR? Also remember the accountName != projectId. The accountName you need to specify with the P12 keys (not at all required with JSON files).

Currently I don't have the bandwidth to dive into gcloud-java-core. So I probably abandon the PR for now and experiment with setting the GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS in the Apache Airflow DataFlowJavaOperator.
@amitsela does this PR also resolve [BEAM-15](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-15)?

@staslev it supposedly does so since DStreams and RDDs are treated separately now. That was the reason for my comment on your PR #901.
Would you mind testing to see if this PR does resolve this issue ?

I think the amount of code in EvaluationContext and StreamingEvaluationContext can be reduced if pcollections map and pstreams maps (respectively) are united into one map in EvaluationContext which will hold values of an abstract class which will be implemented by a DStream wrapper and an RDD wrapper. Many of the methods in both context classes can then be extracted to this new abstract class.
@staslev I agree. Could you open a ticket ? Thanks.

LGTM. 
Ping @jasonkuster ?
Yes I understand that account name != project id, I was just saying that integrating with gcloud-java-core would also improve our experience since they expose more methods for credentials.
R: @dhalperi
LGTM
Closing this and creating a new one

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.
Updated.
I'm checking why Jenkins is failing.

Oh, I think I found the cause of the issue: embedded MongoDB uses `/tmp` to store the artifacts. I think Jenkins don't allow this. I'm changing the location of the MongoDB storage to use the `target` folder and give a try.
Testing if it works on Jenkins with the MongoDB instance located in the target folder.

LGTM. Thank you @mariapython

R: @dhalperi 

Dan, this is part of the effort to update the documentation. This PR changes the examples to use the correct APIs. As a follow up to this there will be a rewrite of the remaining parts of this README (@hadarhod87) to correct names and references.

Tests are still failed on Jenkins (whereas they work fine on my machine):

```
com.mongodb.MongoTimeoutException: Timed out after 30000 ms while waiting for a server that matches WritableServerSelector. Client view of cluster state is {type=UNKNOWN, servers=[{address=0.0.0.0:27017, type=UNKNOWN, state=CONNECTING, exception={com.mongodb.MongoSocketOpenException: Exception opening socket}, caused by {java.net.SocketTimeoutException: connect timed out}}]
```

I saw in the log that a socket file is open in `/tmp` folder, it could be related. I'm checking.

I think you need to use a @TemporaryFolder rule to get the tmp location http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12400243/what-is-the-correct-way-to-write-to-temp-file-during-unit-tests-with-maven

Other than that - please fix the batching in the sink, and I think it'll be good to go! Thanks for bearing with me!

LGTM, merged. Close PR at your leisure.

Btw, when I rebase & squash (see the contribution guide) the commits we need a good way to set the commit message. One option (preferred, I think) is to use the first commit message. Since the first commit message was not especially informative, I wrote a new one based on the PR title.

(Does that make sense?)
LGTM, merged.
LGTM, merged after manually making sure `mvn verify` still passes.
R: @dhalperi
LGTM, merged. Close PR at your leisure.

Thank you @dhalperi 

My opinion is that the first commit message or the PR message should have a very good description of the change and could be used as the summary commit message after squash. Follow up commits are usually fixups and they don't usually change the nature of the PR. Of course there are exceptions to the rule.

It would be useful if we can update the contribution guide (or maybe more practically the PR template) to encourage everyone to have a very informative PR message.
sgtm.
Thanks!
LGTM. Will merge when green, or harass any committer if I end up getting sidetracked
LGTM, merged.

Actually, on that last sentence, it's actually `getDefaultCreateCoder` should have that `checkArgument` - we can accept an empty elems Iterable if the user then specifies their coder; but we must have a coder by apply time.

I'm not sure for @TemporaryFolder: the problem is that the EmbeddedMongoDB uses java.io.tmpdir by default. So, I changed that to the storage location (and use target). Let me check for the socket file.
